job_title: Work Study Student in Lakeland, FL
pros: FSC has plenty of work-study opportunities for students. If you're really on top of things and reach out to different departments directly (rather than check online) you can take on multiple work-study jobs if needed.
cons:
Definitely consider your interests. Some opportunities are not as rewarding as other. As a game worker, you get called in and don't have a consistent schedule if they end up "hiring" a lot of students.

Also it's work-study...don't expect to get paid any more than minimum wage.

pros:
Caring faculty
Students who care and want to make a difference
cons: One of the most backward places to work on the planet. My experience was awful due to the following: President only cares about herself and her image. She drives a tremendous amount of re-work constantly. Administration just salutes her when she has a whim. If they say no to her she fires them. Toxic environment. HR is in her pocket. Don't care about students. You will never get promoted. Pay is about as low as you can imagine and raises don't happen for years at a time.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: The campus itself is beautiful as it is a Frank Lloyd Wright campus but other than that there are no pros.
cons: The president of the college needs to go. Everyone is terrified of her and seems miserable in their jobs but too afraid to leave. Very toxic environment to work in. Students make constant complaints about food, mold, poor leadership and nothing is done. Florida Southern College students and the community deserve better.

pros: Application and setting up interview was a very smooth process. It did take quite a while to hear back from HR for job offer but nothing too crazy. Welcome class was nice and inviting and allowed you time to learn about the school, employment, benefits, etc
cons: I had some problems come up with my supervisor and when I had to escalate to HR, I felt completely blown off and humiliated. They treated me like trash and I would not recommend working for this company.

review_title: FSC gem of the independent college market poised for breakout
pros: The location in central Florida is great! Near beaches, between two major metro areas, but still a small city with its own identity. The center of culture for the area - the campus is a stimulating environment. The faculty and staff enjoy a level of colleagiality that is genuine and refreshing - we truly get along. All in all the campus is a comfortable place to spend a career. There is sufficient intellectual stimulation, a realistic amount of academic freedom, a good vision for the future, and sincere administrators working hard to make it happen. Once you join the community it is hard to leave.
cons: The pay is seriously below market and needs to be addressed. The board and administration have set goals, but we fail to fund the goals and we fall further behind. The inequity of workload among members of the faculty - a core group tackles most of the heavy lifting and the majority ride along pleasantly pursuing their own self interests. The college has big plans for the future, but lacks the operational financial resources to move on many of the most significant plans. Although functionally sufficient, the campus is technologically deprived and needs more of a committment to this vital aspect of college life.

job_title: Library Student Assistant in Lakeland, FL
pros: Schedule works around classes and you can drop or pick up shifts as needed
cons: Can be boring or slow some days

review_title: Beautiful place to work, very few complaints!
job_title: Computer Lab Monitor in Lakeland, FL
pros:
beautiful campus, very nice people, decent benefits for being part time, lax atmosphere, steady hours (sort of)

as a PT employee, you are given vacation time after 60 days, depending on when you start -- i got a full 2 weeks which is unheard of in most PT positions. the majority of the people working there have been there a while and are very nice to be around. i worked around security a lot and they showed me around some really cool places on campus. i was also given a personal trainer at the gym. Dr Kerr is a tad intimidating (she's the president!) but she is a very nice woman. i had a lot of personal things going on in my life when i took this job and my manager tried her best to work with me. that says a lot about the atmosphere, IMO.

if you are looking for a decent part time position as a student or a second job, this is a great place.
cons:
99.99% chance you will NOT get a promotion or ever be full time, the payrate is not terrible but they could definitely afford to pay employees more (its a $40k/year school after all!), the parking situation is horrendous, no advancement in some departments

i was hired PT but with 36 hours/week. after the ACA mandate in Oct '13, i was cut to 29 hours/week so they would not have to provide me with healthcare or other benefits. that's a huge cut and there was no notice given nor was there any kind of compensation for it. that equates to losing a couple hundred dollars a month and was eventually why i left my position. there is also no way to get above those 29 hours/week and in my department, there was absolutely no where to advance to. as for parking...it's a medium size population campus (i guess?) and the students overrun the parking areas (and park horribly). there is absolutely no where for employees to park and some days i'd spend 15-20 mins looking for a spot and would end up four blocks away from my building.

review_title: Great Opportunity to Create Long-Term Work Skills
pros:
• Supportive and receptive of individual opinions and ideas.
• Ability for counselors to go to conferences and continue to grow their skill toolkit.
• Team building trips in the summer ranging from dinners to Disney World trips.
• The VP of enrollment management (John Grundig) is a great leader and does his very best to make sure his staff is performing optimally. 
• Great benefits package
cons: • Long hours especially in the fall due to travel for college fairs, as well as multiple call nights per week. Burnout is very common.

pros: Great leadership with excellent vision for the future of the company as well as emplyees and students.  Leadership shows genuine care and concern for all associated with this organization.  Many opportunities to be successful in career advancement and promotion.
cons: Work days can be long with minimal down time.  High turnover rate.

pros: It was very easy to find an on-campus job in your field of choice, and the flexibility of the job made it very easy to integrate with my schedule.
cons: Low pay and low hours, but this is to be expected when working alongside a full-time degree program.

pros: The people are friendly overall. It is a great location. The benefits are good.
cons: There are a lot of political things. Not a lot of advancement available. They do not have enough people working there so each person has to do a lot of things. Low salary.

pros: Beautiful campus and friendly people.
cons: Horrible teachers and terrible examinations. Financial aid and Registrars people always messing up student accounts. Tuition way to expensive for absolutely no reason. Completely wish I attended a better college.

Employees are expected to do things that are not in their contract.  The focus is on money, not education.  There appear to be jealousies between several management personnel.
